{{About|the Australian Army officer|the Australian cricketer|Michael Slater}} {{Infobox military person |name = Michael David Slater |birth_place = [[Brisbane]], [[Queensland]] |death_place = |image = |caption = |nickname = Mick |allegiance = {{flag|Australia}} |serviceyears = 1978 – Present |rank = [[Major General (Australia)|Major General]] |branch = [[Australian Army]] |commands = [[1st Division (Australia)|1st Division]]
Joint Task Force 630
[[3rd Brigade (Australia)|3rd Brigade]]
[[2nd Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment]] |unit = |battles = [[International Force for East Timor]]
[[Operation Astute]] |awards = [[Distinguished Service Cross (Australia)|Distinguished Service Cross]]
[[Member of the Order of Australia]]
[[Conspicuous Service Cross]] |laterwork= }} [[Major General (Australia)|Major General]] '''Michael David (Mick) Slater''' [[Distinguished Service Cross (Australia)|DSC]], [[Order of Australia|AM]], [[Conspicuous Service Cross (Australia)|CSC]] is a senior officer in the [[Australian Army]]. ==Early life== Mick Slater was born in [[Brisbane, Queensland]], and educated at St Josephâs College Gregory Terrace. He later worked and studied his way through the [[Queensland University of Technology]], joining the Australian Army in 1978, attending the [[Officer Cadet School, Portsea]].[http://web.archive.org/web/20080730072915/http://www.defence.gov.au/leaders/other/mickSlater/index.htm Defence Leaders' Biography] archived from [http://www.defence.gov.au/leaders/other/mickSlater/index.htm the original] on 30 July 2008 ==Service history== Slater has commanded at all levels from platoon to brigade level. His operational commands have included the [[2nd Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment]], and the 3rd Brigade on operations in [[East Timor]], during [[International Force for East Timor]] (INTERFET). Slater was awarded the [[Distinguished Service Cross (Australia)|Distinguished Service Cross]] for his distinguished command and leadership while commander of 2RAR on Operation Warden, in East Timor.[http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=917155&search_type=quick&showInd=true It's an Honour] - Distinguished Service Cross Also he served as an operations staff officer in the United States 3rd Army Headquarters in [[Kuwait]] on Operation Pollard. He has undertaken formal education in mobilisation planning in the [[United States of America]], and is a graduate of the [[Army Command and Staff College]] [[Fort Queenscliff]], the [[Joint Services Command and Staff College]], and the [[U.S. Army War College]]. Slater holds Mastersâ Degrees in Strategic Studies and Business Administration.[http://www.conference.afp.gov.au/speakers_slater.htm International Policing] - Speakers Slater is currently serving as Commander Deployable Joint Force Headquarters, having previously held the position of Head Personnel Executive. In January 2011, Slater was appointed to lead the Flood Recovery Taskforce overseeing recovery from the [[2010â2011 Queensland floods]].{{cite news|title=Flood recovery leader appointed |url=http://www.smh.com.au/environment/weather/flood-recovery-leader-appointed-20110105-19fad.html|accessdate=9 January 2011|newspaper=Sydney Morning Herald|date=5 January 2011}} This taskforce subsequently transitioned into the Queensland Reconstruction Authority, where Slater remained until the 31st August 2011, formally handing over to former Director of the [[Defence Intelligence Organisation]] Major General [[Richard Wilson (general)|Richard Wilson]]. ==Personal== Mick Slater is married to Danielle and has three adult children from a previous marriage. He appeared on the Chaser's War On Everything because of his smart remarks to a newsreader.[http://www.defence.gov.au/dpe/dpe_site/branches/hdpe/hdpe_bio.htm HPE Biography]{{Dead link|date=October 2009}} ==Honours and awards==
